title: Comparing computational entropies below majority (or: When is the dense model theorem false?)

sections.related work:
Computational entropy was studied systematically in 
and is relevant to various problems in complexity and cryptography such as
leakage-resilience ,
constructions of PRGs from one-way functions
 [ref]21 .
and derandomization . There are a number of definitions of computational entropy which we don‚Äôt
consider in this work. For example, Yao pseudoentropy  (see also ), corresponding to random
variables which are ‚Äòcompressible‚Äô by a class of tests ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}, in the sense that ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}
can encode and decode the random variable by encoding into a small number of bits.
Yao pseudoentropy was recently used in time-efficient hardness-to-randomness tradeoffs ,
where (randomness-efficient) samplers for pseudodense distributions were used with an
appropriate extractor to construct a pseudorandom distribution.
Another example is inaccessible entropy of Haitner et al. [ref]21,
corresponding to the entropy of a message at some round in a two-player protocol
conditioned on the prior messages and the randomness of the players, which is used
in efficient constructions of statistically hiding commitment schemes
from one-way functions . Separating notions of computational entropy has been studied before
in , who prove a separation of
pseudodensity and having a dense model for bounded-width
read-once branching programs. Separating notions of conditional computational entropy
was studied in , showing
separations between conditional variants
of Yao pseudoentropy and having a dense model. As mentioned in , citing 
and personal communication with Impagliazzo, another question of interest is whether
Yao pseudoentropy (corresponding to efficient encoding/decoding algorithms)
implies having dense model. It is not hard to see that small Yao pseudoentropy
implies small pseudodensity, with some mild restrictions on ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}. It would be
interesting to see if the techniques from this paper can be used to understand
Yao pseudoentropy in more detail. We leave this to future work. Prior work on the complexity of dense model theorems has
included a tight lower bound on the query complexity 
and a lower bound on the advice complexity .
As far as we are aware, this is the first work to consider the computational complexity
of dense model theorems. There has also been prior work on the computational complexity of hardness amplification, establishing that various
known strategies for hardness amplification require the computation of majority    . It is known that a particular type of hardness amplification given by the hardcore lemma implies the dense model theorem . Our results are stronger in the following sense:
previous work    shows that black-box hardness amplification proofs
require majority. This means that if you amplify the hardness of fùëìf in some black-box way,
then this can be used to compute majority. In our case, we simply show (in different settings)
that the dense model theorem is false, regardless of how we tried to prove it.
By the connection between the hardcore lemma and the dense model theorem, our results
also provide scenarios where the hardcore lemma is false. As far as we are aware,
these are the first such scenarios recorded in the literature.
